linkTarget.anchoringText: This increases vapor production, as seen in Figure 1, which is primarily steam vapor from wells. This results in increased casing pressures. In order to maximize oil production, annular pressure in wells must be minimized to maximize the pressure difference between the reservoir and the well to maximize oil inflow (Sardoff et al 1997). This paper will refer to this produced gas as produced steam. In an attempt to relieve the casing pressure on the individual wellbores, a CVR system has been installed.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Sardoff generalized reservoir description of produced steam

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sardoff generalized reservoir description of produced steam

linkTarget.anchoringText: The CVR system consists of flowlines off the casing from individual wells which are tied into trunk lines and then feed to vapor recovery traps. The traps separate the liquid (condensate) from the vapor phase. The vapor phase is then sent through cooling fans to allow for separation of any remaining liquids before the gas phase is compressed. Due to well spacing seen in Figure 2, the locations of the individual wells from the compression sites can often exceed a mile in distance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Aerial map depicting distance from individual wells to gas compression site.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Aerial map depicting distance from individual wells to gas compression site.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Historically, spring and summer seasons see decreased CVR system efficiency due to increased ambient air temperature (Figure 3) resulting in less cooling efficiency prior to compression. In order to eliminate operational issues and equipment damage, total gas flow into the CVR system must be decreased. Prior to this project, operations had experienced several process upsets due to the low equipment efficiency.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Ambient air temperature in Lost Hills showing seasonal effect in summer and winter

formatted-caption.caption-text: Ambient air temperature in Lost Hills showing seasonal effect in summer and winter

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Average wellhead casing pressure for wells in Lost Hills

formatted-caption.caption-text: Average wellhead casing pressure for wells in Lost Hills

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Variables and assumptions for equations for calculating flow across a fixed choke from SPE 24081

formatted-caption.caption-text: Variables and assumptions for equations for calculating flow across a fixed choke from SPE 24081

linkTarget.anchoringText: These inputs in Figure 6 were modeled using advanced analytics and multivariate analysis methods to generate a calculated gas volume. The inputs were compared to a steam table, which confirmed that the gas makeup is primarily steam. The calculated gas volumes were compared to the actual measured gas volumes from the third party vendor. The model predicted gas volumes accurately for high gas volumes (greater than 30 BSPD) within +/-20% of actual steam volumes.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Input variables for the advanced analytic model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Input variables for the advanced analytic model

linkTarget.anchoringText: Once the analytical solution was validated with field measurements and the PSOR report generated daily, the process for trouble shooting CVR pressure increases was changed. An operations culture shift was required. Operators targeted wells by PSOR (Figure 7) instead of relying on tacit knowledge. Operations had to adjust their mindset to proactively shutoff more wells which had a low total oil volume impact rather than a single, high gas producing well that could also be a high oil producing well. The individual well culprit of the upset condition may be left unchanged, but the overall system pressure is managed.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Example of PSOR ranked list. CVR valves are closed in order of top to bottom in upset conditions.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of PSOR ranked list. CVR valves are closed in order of top to bottom in upset conditions.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This new process optimizes oil production by targeting low oil producers for CVR shut-in. The analytic solution has successfully prevented CVR maximum pressure shutdowns during high temperature months while, simultaneously optimizing oil production. This field study was successful in lowering the operational temperature by 6 Degrees Fahrenheit (Figure 9) and lowering operational pressure by 0.6 psig (Figure 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: CVR system pressure before and after analytical solution and PSOR list implemented

formatted-caption.caption-text: CVR system pressure before and after analytical solution and PSOR list implemented

linkTarget.anchoringText: This new process optimizes oil production by targeting low oil producers for CVR shut-in. The analytic solution has successfully prevented CVR maximum pressure shutdowns during high temperature months while, simultaneously optimizing oil production. This field study was successful in lowering the operational temperature by 6 Degrees Fahrenheit (Figure 9) and lowering operational pressure by 0.6 psig (Figure 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: CVR system temperature before and after analytical solution and PSOR list implemented
